q: How do you add a border to an element?
rationale: Shorthand: width, style, color.

q: How do you hide an element so it takes up no space?
rationale: display: none removes the element from flow.

q: How do you select all &ltp&gt elements inside a &ltdiv&gt?
rationale: The descendant selector matches all nested elements.

q: How do you select all elements with the class 'container'?
rationale: Classes use the dot (.) prefix.

q: How do you select an element with id 'demo'?
rationale: IDs are selected with the # symbol.

q: How do you select elements with class name 'test'?
rationale: Classes are selected with the . symbol.

q: What does 'fixed' position relate an element to?
rationale: Fixed elements stay put even when scrolling the window.

q: What does 'opacity: 0' do?
options: Hides element and keeps in layout
rationale: The element is invisible but still occupies layout space.

q: What is the correct CSS syntax to make all &ltp&gt elements bold?
rationale: Element selector + font-weight.

q: What is the default value of 'display' for a &ltdiv&gt?
rationale: Divs are block-level elements.

q: What is the default value of 'display' for a &ltspan&gt?
rationale: Spans are inline elements.

q: What is the default value of 'flex-direction'?
rationale: Flexbox defaults to horizontal layout (row).

q: What is the default value of the 'position' property?
rationale: Elements are 'static' by default, following normal flow.

q: What is the result of 'color: #000'?
rationale: #000 is hex for black.

q: What is the standard order of the box model layers from inside to outside?
rationale: Content is innermost, Padding surrounds content, Border surrounds padding, and Margin is the outermost space.

q: Which CSS property is used to specify the transparency of an element?
rationale: opacity ranges from 0 to 1.

q: Which CSS property is used to stack elements on top of each other?
rationale: z-index controls the 3D depth/stacking.

q: Which CSS unit is equal to 1% of the viewport height?
rationale: vh stands for Viewport Height.

q: Which CSS unit is relative to the font-size of the root element?
rationale: 'rem' stands for Root EM.

q: Which Grid property defines the number and size of columns?
rationale: grid-template-columns sets layout structure.

q: Which property centers a flex container's items vertically (cross-axis)?
rationale: align-items handles the cross-axis.

q: Which property changes the background color?
rationale: background-color sets the element background.

q: Which property changes the list item marker (e.g. bullet point, number or roman numeral)?
rationale: list-style-type allows choosing markers.

q: Which property controls the text size?
rationale: font-size defines the size of the font.

q: Which property creates a transition effect?
rationale: transition defines how properties change over time.

q: Which property creates space outside an element's border?
rationale: Margin creates space outside the border.

q: Which property defines how to capitalize text?
rationale: text-transform (uppercase, capitalize) handles case.

q: Which property defines the font thickness?
rationale: font-weight is used for bolding.

q: Which property defines whether a background image scrolls with the page?
rationale: background-attachment can be 'fixed' or 'scroll'.

q: Which property is used to add a line over, under, or through text?
rationale: text-decoration handles underlines and strikethroughs.

q: Which property is used to add a shadow to a box?
rationale: box-shadow adds shadows to container elements.

q: Which property is used to add space between letters?
rationale: letter-spacing controls the gap between characters.

q: Which property is used to add space inside an element's border?
rationale: Padding is internal spacing.

q: Which property is used to align text?
rationale: text-align sets horizontal alignment.

q: Which property is used to change the font of an element?
rationale: font-family specifies the typeface.

q: Which property is used to change the left margin of an element?
rationale: margin-left targets the specific side.

q: Which property is used to change the left padding of an element?
rationale: padding-left targets internal space on the left.

q: Which property is used to change the mouse cursor?
rationale: The cursor property (e.g., pointer) changes the UI icon.

q: Which property is used to justify items along the main axis in Flexbox?
rationale: justify-content handles horizontal alignment in rows.

q: Which property is used to rotate an element?
rationale: rotate(deg) is the standard method.

q: Which property is used to set the color of a border?
rationale: border-color changes the border line color.

q: Which property is used to set the spacing between lines of text?
rationale: line-height controls vertical text rhythm.

q: Which property is used to wrap text in a flex container?
rationale: flex-wrap: wrap allows items to move to a new line.

q: Which property makes the text bold?
rationale: font-weight sets thickness.

q: Which property sets the background image?
rationale: background-image: url() is the standard syntax.

q: Which selector styles a link that the user is currently clicking?
rationale: The :active state triggers during the click.

q: Which selector styles an element when the mouse is over it?
rationale: The :hover pseudo-class triggers on mouseover.

q: How many columns are in the default Bootstrap grid system?
rationale: Bootstrap's grid system is based on a 12-column layout.

q: Which class provides a full-width container, spanning the entire width of the viewport?
rationale: .container-fluid provides a full width container, whereas .container has a fixed responsive width.

q: Which class is used to create a primary blue button?
rationale: .btn-primary is the standard Bootstrap class for the primary action button (usually blue).

q: Which class is used to make an image scale with its parent element?
rationale: In Bootstrap 4 and 5, .img-fluid is used to make images responsive (max-width: 100% and height: auto).

q: What is the correct utility class for adding a top margin of 3 units?
rationale: Bootstrap uses shorthand for spacing: 'm' for margin, 't' for top, and a scale from 0-5.

q: Which of the following represents the color black in the RGB color model?
rationale: In the RGB (Red, Green, Blue) model, black is the absence of all light, represented by the value 0 for each component.

q: What is the correct hexadecimal representation for the color blue?
rationale: Hexadecimal color codes follow the #RRGGBB format. #0000FF sets the blue intensity to the maximum (FF) while red and green are at 0.

q: In HTML, which attribute is used to specify an image's source?
rationale: The 'src' attribute points to the image file.

q: What does the &ltnav&gt element represent?
rationale: &ltnav&gt is semantic markup for major navigation blocks.

q: What is the correct HTML for adding a background color?
rationale: Inline styles use the 'style' attribute.

q: What is the correct HTML for creating a hyperlink?
rationale: The 'href' attribute is required for &lta&gt tags.

q: What is the correct HTML for making a checkbox?
rationale: Checkboxes use &ltinput type='checkbox'&gt.

q: What is the correct HTML for making a text input field?
rationale: Standard text input uses type='text'.

q: What is the correct tag for a line break?
rationale: &ltbr&gt is an empty element used to create a single line break.

q: Which HTML element defines a multi-line input field?
rationale: The &lttextarea&gt element allows for multi-line text.

q: Which HTML element is used to define an ordered list?
rationale: &ltol&gt creates a numbered list.

q: Which HTML element is used to define an unordered list?
rationale: &ltul&gt creates a bulleted list.

q: Which HTML element is used to specify a header for a document or section?
rationale: &ltheader&gt represents introductory content.

q: Which HTML element is used to specify a multi-line text input field?
rationale: &lttextarea&gt is used for long text entries.

q: Which HTML5 element represents an independent piece of content?
rationale: &ltarticle&gt is for content that could be distributed independently, like a blog post.

q: Which HTML5 tag is used to embed a video?
rationale: The &ltvideo&gt element is the HTML5 standard for video playback.

q: Which attribute defines the relationship between a link and the current document?
rationale: The 'rel' attribute (e.g., rel='stylesheet') defines the link type.

q: Which attribute provides a unique identifier for an element?
rationale: The 'id' attribute must be unique within an HTML document.

q: Which attribute specifies an image's description for screen readers?
rationale: The 'alt' attribute provides alternative text.

q: Which attribute specifies an input field to be mandatory input?
rationale: The 'required' attribute enforces client-side validation.

q: Which attribute specifies the document type?
rationale: &lt!DOCTYPE html&gt is the first line of a HTML5 document.

q: Which attribute specifies where to open a linked document?
rationale: The 'target' attribute (e.g., _blank) tells the browser where to open the link.

q: Which attribute specifies where to send the form-data when a form is submitted?
rationale: The 'action' attribute contains the URL for processing.

q: Which attribute is used to provide a tooltip for an element?
rationale: The 'title' attribute displays text when hovering.

q: Which character is used to indicate an end tag?
rationale: The forward slash / indicates the closing of a tag.

q: Which element defines an image in an HTML page?
rationale: The &ltimg&gt tag is used to embed images.

q: Which element defines emphasized text?
rationale: &ltem&gt is semantic for emphasis.

q: Which element defines important text?
rationale: &ltstrong&gt indicates strong importance.

q: Which element defines the main content of the document?
rationale: &ltmain&gt should be unique to the document.

q: Which element defines the title of the document (shown in browser tab)?
rationale: The &lttitle&gt tag appears in the browser's title bar.

q: Which element groups related elements in a form?
rationale: &ltfieldset&gt draws a box around related form elements.

q: Which element is used for the most important heading?
rationale: &lth1&gt defines the most important heading on a page.

q: Which element is used to draw a line across the whole page?
rationale: &lthr&gt draws a horizontal rule.

q: Which element is used to group the body content in a table?
rationale: &lttbody&gt wraps the data rows of a table.

q: Which element represents a summary or caption for the &ltdetails&gt element?
rationale: &ltsummary&gt is the visible heading for the toggle.

q: Which method is used for sending sensitive form data?
rationale: POST is more secure as data is sent in the body.

q: Which tag defines a button that can be clicked?
rationale: Both &ltinput type='submit'&gt and &ltbutton&gt create clickable buttons.

q: Which tag defines a client-side script?
rationale: &ltscript&gt is used for JavaScript.

q: Which tag defines a drop-down list?
rationale: The &ltselect&gt element creates a picklist.

q: Which tag defines a table row?
rationale: &lttr&gt stands for Table Row.

q: Which tag defines an inline frame?
rationale: &ltiframe&gt embeds another page within the current one.

q: Which tag defines an option in a drop-down list?
rationale: &ltoption&gt elements go inside &ltselect&gt.

q: Which tag defines the beginning of a cell in a table?
rationale: &lttd&gt is for standard cells; &ltth&gt is for header cells.

q: Which tag is for self-contained illustrative content with captions?
rationale: &ltfigure&gt combined with &ltfigcaption&gt is semantic.

q: Which tag is used to create an interactive widget that can be opened or closed?
rationale: &ltdetails&gt allows users to hide or reveal content.

q: Which tag is used to define a container for an external (non-HTML) application?
rationale: &ltembed&gt and &ltobject&gt are both used for external plug-ins.

q: Which HTML element is used for marking up search results?
rationale: &ltmark&gt is often used to highlight relevant search terms.

q: Which HTML element is used to embed a sound file?
rationale: The &ltaudio&gt tag is the standard for sound.

q: Difference between 'let' and 'var'?
options: let is function-scoped; var is block-scoped
let is block-scoped; var is function-scoped
rationale: let provides better scoping.

q: How do you call 'myFunction'?
rationale: Call using name and parentheses.

q: How do you check if a value is Not-a-Number?
rationale: isNaN() is the standard global function to check for NaN.

q: How do you create a new Person object?
rationale: The 'new' keyword creates an instance.

q: How do you declare a JS variable?
rationale: var, let, or const are valid.

q: How do you declare a variable who value cannot be modified?
rationale: const is for constants.

q: How do you find the highest value of x and y?
rationale: Math.max returns the largest number.

q: How do you round 7.25 to the nearest integer?
rationale: Math.round() is the correct method.

q: How do you start a 'for' loop?
rationale: For loops require initialization, condition, and increment.

q: How do you write 'Hello World' in an alert box?
rationale: alert() is the standard method.

q: How do you write a comment?
rationale: // is for single-line comments.

q: How do you write a conditional for 'not equal'?
rationale: != is the loose inequality operator.

q: How do you write the standard way to write an array?
rationale: Square brackets [] are for array literals.

q: How many parameters can be passed to a function?
rationale: Functions can take any amount of arguments.

q: How to get a random number between 0 and 1?
rationale: Math.random() returns 0 to &lt1.

q: Result of '2' + 2?
rationale: String + Number results in concatenation.

q: Result of 2 + 2 + '2'?
rationale: Left to right: 4 then concat '2'.

q: What does DOM stand for?
rationale: It is the tree structure of an HTML page.

q: What is 'typeof []'?
rationale: Arrays are technically objects in JS.

q: What is the correct syntax for a function?
rationale: Function declarations start with 'function'.

q: What is the default value of an uninitialized variable?
rationale: Variables declared but not assigned are undefined.

q: What is the purpose of 'use strict'?
rationale: Strict mode prevents common silent errors.

q: What is the result of '10' * 2?
rationale: Multiplication triggers numeric coercion of the string.

q: What is the result of '10' - 5?
rationale: JavaScript coerces the string '10' to a number when using the subtraction operator.

q: What is the result of 5 === '5'?
rationale: Strict equality (===) returns false because the data types (number vs string) differ.

q: What is the return type of 'typeof []'?
rationale: Arrays are specialized objects in JavaScript.

q: What is the scope of a variable declared with 'var' inside a function?
rationale: Var is scoped to the nearest function context.

q: What is the value of an uninitialized variable?
rationale: Variables without values are undefined.

q: What result does '3' === 3 give?
rationale: Strict equality fails because string != number.

q: What will 10 + '5' result in?
rationale: The + operator performs concatenation when a string is present.

q: What will 10 - '5' result in?
rationale: The - operator forces numeric coercion.

q: What will 'Boolean(10 &gt 9)' return?
rationale: 10 &gt 9 is true.

q: Which adds an element to the end of an array?
rationale: push() adds to the end.

q: Which comparison operator checks for inequality?
rationale: != is for values; !== is for value or type.

q: Which event occurs when a user clicks an element?
rationale: The onclick handler triggers on clicks.

q: Which event triggers when the user leaves an input field?
rationale: onblur is the opposite of onfocus.

q: Which function converts string to a whole number?
rationale: parseInt() parses a string to an integer.

q: Which function is used to execute a block of code after a delay?
rationale: setTimeout() runs code once after ms delay.

q: Which function parses a string and returns a floating point number?
rationale: parseFloat() handles decimals.

q: Which keyword is used to declare a block-scoped variable?
rationale: let and const are block-scoped, introduced in ES6.

q: Which keyword is used to define a function?
rationale: function is the declaration keyword.

q: Which keyword is used to exit a loop?
rationale: break immediately terminates the current loop.

q: Which keyword is used to handle exceptions?
rationale: try...catch stops crashes from errors.

q: Which keyword refers to the current object?
rationale: 'this' refers to the current execution context.

q: Which loop will always execute at least once?
rationale: A do...while loop executes the code block once before checking the condition.

q: Which method adds an element to the front of an array?
rationale: unshift() adds to the beginning of the array.

q: Which method adds elements to the end of an array?
rationale: push() appends to the end.

q: Which method adds elements to the start of an array?
rationale: unshift() adds to the beginning.

q: Which method changes the content of an HTML element?
rationale: innerHTML and textContent are standard.

q: Which method combines arrays?
rationale: concat() returns a joined array.

q: Which method creates a new array by performing a function on each element?
rationale: map() returns a modified copy of the array.

q: Which method extracts a section of an array and returns a new array?
rationale: slice() does not modify the original array.

q: Which method joins two or more strings?
rationale: concat() joins string or array elements.

q: Which method removes the first element from an array?
rationale: shift() removes from the front and offsets indices.

q: Which method removes the last element from an array?
rationale: pop() removes and returns the last element.

q: Which method removes whitespace from both ends of a string?
rationale: trim() handles leading and trailing spaces.

q: Which method returns a substring?
rationale: slice() extracts part of a string.

q: Which method returns string length?
rationale: .length is a string property.

q: Which method returns the character at a specific index in a string?
rationale: charAt(index) is a string method.

q: How can you obtain the length of a string?
rationale: .length is the property that returns the length of a string.

q: Which method rounds a number up to the nearest integer?
rationale: Math.ceil() always rounds up to the nearest integer.

q: Which method is used to round a number to the nearest integer?
rationale: Math.round() follows standard rounding rules, by rounding down when the number is below 0.5 and rounding up at 0.5 or higher.

q: Which method is used to find an element by its ID?
rationale: getElementById is the most efficient lookup.

q: Which method is used to output a message to the debugger?
rationale: console.log() is standard for debugging.

q: Which of these is a valid 'if' statement?
rationale: Conditionals require parentheses.

q: Which object allows you to work with dates?
rationale: The Date object handles time and calendar data.

q: Which object is used for mathematical tasks?
rationale: The Math object provides constants and functions.

q: Which operator assigns a value?
rationale: The single equals sign is for assignment.

q: Which operator is used to check for both value and type equality?
rationale: === is the strict equality operator.

q: Which operator is used to find the remainder of a division?
rationale: The modulo operator (%) returns the remainder.

q: Which operator is used for multiplication?
rationale: The asterisk * is used.

q: Which part of the Event Loop monitors the Call Stack and moves tasks from the Callback Queue?
rationale: The Event Loop continuously checks if the stack is empty to process the queue.

q: Which statement is used to perform different actions based on different conditions?
rationale: Both switch and if/else handle conditional logic.

q: Which statement exits a loop?
rationale: break terminates the current loop.

q: Which symbol is used for comments?
rationale: // is for lines; /* */ is for blocks.

q: Which symbol is used for logical AND?
rationale: && is the logical AND operator in JavaScript.

q: Which symbol is used for logical OR?
rationale: || is the logical OR operator in JavaScript.

q: Which variable name is invalid?
rationale: Variable names cannot start with a number.

q: Which symbol is used as a shortcut for the jQuery function?
rationale: The '$' sign is the standard shorthand alias for the 'jQuery()' function, used to select and manipulate elements.

q: Which jQuery method is used to hide selected elements?
rationale: The '.hide()' method is a built-in jQuery function that hides elements by setting their CSS 'display' property to 'none'.

q:
What is the correct jQuery syntax to change the background color of all

elements to red?
rationale: The '.css()' method is used to get or set style properties for selected elements in jQuery.

q: Which jQuery function ensures that the code doesn't run until the DOM is fully loaded?
rationale: The '$(document).ready()' event triggers as soon as the DOM structure is ready, allowing scripts to interact with elements safely.

q: Which jQuery syntax is correctly used to attach a click event to all paragraphs using the .on() method?
rationale: The .on() method takes the event name as the first string argument and the handler function as the second argument.

q: What does the Fetch API return when called?
rationale: The fetch() function returns a Promise that resolves to the Response object representing the response to that request.

q: Which method is used to parse a Fetch response body as JSON?
rationale: The .json() method on the Response object reads the request body to completion and returns a promise that resolves with the result of parsing the body text as JSON.

q: Which property of the Response object should you check to see if a request was successful (status in the range 200-299)?
rationale: The 'ok' property is a boolean indicating whether the response was successful (status in the range 200â€“299).

q: What is the default HTTP method used by the Fetch API if no method is specified?
rationale: By default, fetch() performs a GET request unless the configuration object specifies otherwise.

q: When sending data in a POST request with Fetch, where should the serialized data be placed?
rationale: The payload of a POST request is assigned to the 'body' property of the options object passed to fetch().

q: What is the initial state of a JavaScript Promise?
rationale: A Promise is 'pending' until it either settles as fulfilled or rejected.

q: Which method is used to handle a Promise when it is successfully fulfilled?
rationale: The .then() method takes up to two arguments: callback functions for the success and failure cases of the Promise.

q: How do you handle a rejection or error in a Promise chain?
rationale: The .catch() method is the standard shorthand for handling rejections in a Promise chain.

q: What is the behavior of Promise.all()?
options: It executes promises one after another
It rejects only if all promises reject
It resolves only if all promises resolve
It resolves as soon as the first promise resolves
rationale: Promise.all() waits for all input promises to fulfill and rejects immediately if any of them reject.

q: Which keyword is used to pause the execution of an async function until a Promise settles?
rationale: The await operator is used to wait for a Promise inside an async function.
